discussion.content:
Selected Answer: B
B is the right choice

questions.question_text: An engineer performs a wireless site survey of a multi-floor building for 2.4-GHz and 5-GHz bands. The customer wants to identify non-802.11 sources of interference. Which survey measurement must be included in the survey?

An engineer is deploying new APs to serve IEEE 802.11g through 802.11ac clients and wants to use the Ekahau Site Survey tool to verify RF coverage. Management wants the engineer to verify and create coverage maps as quickly as possible. Which configuration accomplishes the goal?

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: A
Key word is RF coverage.So passive mode is enough and using two wireless adapters will make it faster.

Selected Answer: A
Passive mode and with two wireless adapters, then A is correct, active mode always consumes more time.
Passive mode and with two wireless adaptors , so A is correct

Selected Answer: A
A.
Using passive mode with two wireless adapters in the Ekahau Site Survey tool allows for simultaneous scanning of multiple channels, thereby expediting the creation of accurate RF coverage maps. Active surveys, on the other hand, can be more time-consuming as they require the client device to associate with access points and perform data transfers, which is less efficient for quickly mapping coverage areas.

Selected Answer: C
In active mode, the survey tool actively sends probe requests and receives responses from the wireless network, which provides more detailed and accurate information about the network's performance and coverage. Using two wireless adapters in active mode allows you to simultaneously scan and collect data from multiple channels, significantly speeding up the process and improving the accuracy of your coverage maps

comments.content: but active surveys take more time, the question asks, 'quickly as possible', in this case should be passive.

choices.B: passive mode with one wireless adapter
choices.D: active mode with one wireless adapter
choices.A: passive mode with two wireless adapters
choices.C: active mode with two wireless adapters

questions.question_text: A customer currently is migrating the old wireless infrastructure to a new Cisco IOS XE-based solution and wants a mobility group configured between a Cisco AireOS WLC and an IOS XE WLC. During the migration phase from AireOS to IOS XE, the Layer 3 roaming between the WLCs must be seamless. Which action meets the requirements?

choices.B: For different SSIDs, use different VLAN IDs and subnets on both WLCs.
choices.A: For the same SSIDs, use the same VLAN IDs and subnets on both WLCs.
choices.C: For different SSIDs, use the same VLAN IDs and subnets on both WLCs.
choices.D: For the same SSIDs, use different VLAN IDs and subnets on both WLCs.

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: D
Need to correct my previous answer , since the question is saying Layer 3 roaming, then the VLAN id and subnet should be different

Selected Answer: D
It has to be D. If different SSID then there's no roaming at all. If the same VLAN and subnet then it is not Layer 3 roaming (it's layer 2 roaming).
A is correct , same SSID should be used and to have seamless layer 3 roaming we should use the same VLAN IDs and subnets on both WLCs.

Selected Answer: D
I believe the key word here is `Layer 3`. It they are roaming in Layer 3, each WLC will be in a different subnet

Selected Answer: D
it should be D, Answer A says Inter controller LAyer 2 .

comments.content: Answer is A as I've worked on a project for one of our customers where migrated 5508 to9800 in the same way without causing network disruption.

discussion.content: no answer makes sense to me
D is correct , the other choices dont help optimize roaming

Selected Answer: D
D is the right answer

questions.question_text: An engineer has been tasked with optimizing roaming for all the wireless networks used by shops located in a shopping center. A unique WLAN is assigned to each individual shop named ret470632970B55XX, where the last two digits indicate the shopâ€™s location. The wireless network consists of 9800 controllers and Cisco 9100 APs. What should the engineer configure on the controllers to optimize roaming?

choices.A: assign access rules based on location

discussion.content: D is correct , since we need -67dBm and 15 to 20% intercell overlap

questions.question_text: An IT administrator is trying to establish the criteria for a predictive coverage design. The environment is a mix of 802.11g data and voice. Which minimum coverage with SNR 25 aligns with Cisco best practice?
